content.description: Joey's first half is quite easy but a bit run out to the second bolt.  The hard moves start just above the third bolt.  The first crux is thin hands and feet until you get hands over the small overhang.  The second crux is getting your feet over the overhang.
content.protection: The 6 bolts can be supplemented with additional gear in a couple places to ease nerves if need be.  2 bolt anchors for belaying on top.
content.location: Even though Joey's is technically on the upper tier, you reach it by walking left from the lower tier along a small trail through the bushes and angling up and over boulders after 75 feet or so.  The cliff is only one tier at this end of the cliffs.  The climb is easily recognized by a small clearing at the base of the only nice looking face with a small overhang near the top.  A 60 meter rope just reaches the ground for rappelling.  Otherwise you could walk left off the top and wind down and around the base back to the climb.

content.description: VTI ascends the slab between the 'Diamond Crack Right' and 'Super Slab 4 You'.  The climb starts off ascending a corner for roughly 10-15' until you reach a small roof that gains the slab above.  Protect the transition from the corner to moving onto the slab by placing a #1 or #2 cam (w/ sling).  Climb the slab to a ledge (aim for the 'fang' see photo), there are many options to throw in protection on the slab.   Once on the ledge, climb the hand/finger crack to the anchor.  Lower/Rappel from the anchor.
content.protection: Single (or double) rack to #2 BD Camelot.

content.description: Start in an alcove that is near the left end of the Upper Tier and just right of some left slanting cracks. Climb a steep section past a bolt (sporty) onto lower angled rock. Continue up a groove past a couple more bolts and some gear placements to a bulge near the top of the wall. Move right to a bolt and surmount the bulge (crux for some folks) to the top. Rappel/lower from the same anchor as When Joey Comes Marching Home.
content.protection: About 5 bolts, a few TCUs and small to medium cams.
content.location: This route is located roughly 30 feet to the left of When Joey Comes Marching Home (listed here as "Joey's") in an alcove. The alcove is about 30 feet to the right of the left edge of the Upper Tier.

content.description: Easy crack up to a pair of older bolts, but still a lot of fun. Also, easy gear anchor beyond the little juniper tree; and you can rap off Upper Pappy back to the ledge. Probably a good first trad lead for someone to get used to putting gear in cracks.
content.location: on the left side of the middle bench - the only obvious lower angle crack going up and left.

content.description:
Follow the original 'White Streak/Broken Bit' line to the 2nd bolt (the unmistakable white streak on the upper tier).  After the 2nd bolt, veer off of the white streak left up a diagonal bar/seam. to a 3rd bolt (new line and start of RIP).  Continue straight up past a 4th bolt and a piton.

VARIATION:

Startup Rocco's Corner and veer right after getting out of the corner proper.  (5.10a)

Anchor hardware and original bolts have been replaced with new stainless 3/8 hardware.

Now that you have become comfortable on Indian Springs' great, mostly bolted face climbs, you decide to try out a trad 5.9. This climb will truely test your crack climbing techniques, ability to place gear in awkward and difficult stances, and then test your head on the runout face climbing to the anchors!  After scrambling up some class 4 rock you will find yourself on a great platform (with some shade on the right) with the obvious corner/crack above.  Step up right and onto the face and then step left to just below the corner.  Climb the corner past the bulge crux.  Make sure you place a few good pieces in the thin crack above as the runout face to the anchors is quite hard. This is a great route but feels a full grade harder than other 9's in the area.  This is mostly due to the fact that it requires completely different techniques, is all trad, and has a technical runout face section at the end.
content.protection: This route is completely trad where a good selection of small to medium cams and stoppers is required.  A two bolt anchor awaits on top.  20' of class 4 scrambling gets you to the very top of the cliffs.

content.description:
Racing Stripes starts 8ft. or so right of Fire Stone.  The first 2-3 moves off the ground are the crux.  Once past the crux, continue on the easier ground up and through a right trending crack/lie-back placing pro where desired.  There are numerous places for cams .5 and under.  Follow the route up and past the last bolt to the top of the wall.

Lower off Country Bumpkin anchors.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a few cams up to #1
content.location: Located on the upper tier 8ft or so to the right of Fire Stone.

content.description: Start about 50 feet right of When Joey Comes Marching Home at a golden slab with a bolt. Climb the slab up and slightly left to a steeper corner with two bolts. Go up and left through the corner onto a slab. Climb a short left leaning crack above to reach the upper bulge. Step right and pull through the final bulge at a bolt to reach a chain anchor.
content.location: This route is located about 50 feet to the right of When Joey Comes Marching Home (listed here as "Joey's"). There is a golden slab with a bolt at the start of this climb.

climbs.name: Once Upon a Time in the West

content.description:
Left of Rocco's corner.  Start on the blocky terraces below the main slab.  The start is relatively easy, the crux comes in just above the first bolt (up on the slab).

Located between Rocco's Corner and Radical Left.
content.protection: 3 Bolts, use small/med cams on lower portion if necessary.

content.description: Two old bolts/hangers protect the lower section of the climb.  Top is runout to the anchor, but eases up in difficulty.
content.location: Slab route between the white streak and Super Doo.

content.description: Fire Stone starts up and right from Rocco's Corner about 15'.  You must scramble up a little chimney to reach the face which is just right of an obvious easy crack climb called Super Doo (5.2).  Climb up past first bolt through a nicely featured face.  To get to the second bolt, which is quite a ways away, move up and delicately step left just below the bolt.  You would hit the deck if you slipped off here.  Move up to the obvious left facing flake/corner.  This protects well to it's top.  A thin step left off the flake onto the face is the crux with one or two thin moves up to the anchors.  This is a great, fun route with two cruxes, the delicate move left before the second bolt and stepping off the flake at the top although the first is more heady than difficult.
content.protection: Two bolts plus a few additional small to medium trad gear protect this climb adequately.  Anchors are double bolts.  A short 3rd class scramble gets you to the very top of the cliffs.  A fall scrambling would be very bad.

content.description: The crux of Country Bumpkin is getting over the small overhang/flake and clipped to the next bolt.  A fun, thin crux makes for an enjoyable climb. The photo at right is a bit misleading as the photo is very foreshortened.  The overhang/flake is really a little over 1/2 way up.
content.protection: Three bolts are found on the climb but small and large cams add protection to some dicy spots.  Getting clipped to the first bolt over the flake would be scary without gear under the flake and climbing up the last 5.9 face to the top without additional gear after the last bolt would be very bold indeed.
content.location: Country Bumpkin starts on the third tier from the anchors of Pappy Smear.  The climb is really about 75' long.  A bolt about 15' up off the deck is reached by friction climbing up the slab.  Care must be taken on the easier ground all the way to the flake as you are high above your last gear.  A long walk down west around the cliff and back can  be done but there are anchors along the top of the cliff for rappel which is what most people do.
